case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 380 to 389, 391 to 399, 401, 429 and 431 to 434 of 1958

facts.text: Appeals are Civil Appeals Nos. 380 to 389, 391 to 399, 401, 429 and 431 to 434 of 1958 from Allahabad High Court judgment dated December 19, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 380 to 389, 391 to 399, 401, 429 and 431 to 434 of 1958. Appeals from the judgment and decree dated December 19, 1956, of the Allahabad High Court

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petitions in Allahabad High Court challenging U.P. Transport Services Development Act, 1955 (Act IX of 1955) and notifications thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: The said appeals arise out Writ Petitions filed by he appellants in the Allahabad High Court challenging the validity of the U. P. Transport Services  Development  Act of 1955, being U. P. Act No. IX of 1955  hereinafter referred to as the U. P. Act , and the numberifications issued thereunder.

facts.text: Appellants have been carrying on business as stage carriage operators for a considerable number of years on different routes in Uttar Pradesh under valid permits issued under Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants have been carrying on business as stage carriage operators for a companysiderable number of years on different routes in Uttar Pradesh under valid, permits issued under the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939, along with buses owned by Government.

facts.text: U.P. Legislature obtained assent of President on April 23, 1955 and passed U.P. Act, published on April 24, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The U. P. Legislature, after obtaining the assent of the President on April 23, 1955, passed the U. Act and duly published it on April 24, 1955.

facts.text: Government issued notification under s.3 of U.P. Act dated May 17, 1955 directing specified routes to be exclusively served by government stage carriages.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3 of the U. P. Act, the Government issued a numberification dated May 17, 1955, whereunder it was directed that the aforesaid routes along with others should be exclucively served by the stage carriages of the Government

facts.text: State Government published notification under s.4 of U.P. Act formulating scheme on November 12, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On November 12, 1955, the State Government published the numberification under s. 4 of the U. P. Act formulating the scheme for the aforesaid routes among others.

facts.text: Appellants received notices under s.5 of U.P. Act to file objections to the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants received numberices under s. 5 of the U. P. Act requiring them to file objections, if any, to the said scheme

facts.text: Objections heard by Board on January 2, 1956 except Agra region, which was adjourned to January 7, 1956; Agra operators did not appear.

anchor.surface_text: and after the objections were received, they were informed that they would be heard by a Board on January 2, 1956. On that date, the objections filed by the operators other than those of the Agra region were heard and the inquiry in regard to the Agra region was adjourned to January 7, 1956. It appears that the operators of the Agra region did number appear on the 7th.

facts.text: Notification under s.8 of U.P. Act published in U.P. Gazette on June 23, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The numberification issued under s. 8 of the U. P. Act was pub- lished in the U. P. Gazette on June 23, 1956,

facts.text: On June 25, 1956, Secretary to Regional Transport Authority, Agra sent order from Transport Commissioner to Agra operators prohibiting plying on routes and transferring permits.

anchor.surface_text: and on June 25, 1956, the Secretary to the Regional Transport Authority, Agra, sent an order purported to have been issued by the Transport Commissioner to the operators, of the Agra region prohibiting them from plying their stage carriages on the routes and also informing them that their permits would be transferred to other routes.

facts.text: Writ petitions filed in Allahabad High Court challenging U.P. Act and notifications.

anchor.surface_text: On July 7, 1956, a numberice was sent to filed Writ Petitions in the Allahabad High Court challenging the validity of the U. P. Act and the numberifications issued thereunder.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court delivered judgment on December 19, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Allahabad High Court, which is the subject-matter of these appeals, was delivered on December 19, 1956.

facts.text: Motor Vehicles Amendment Act, 1956 (100 of 1956) published on December 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Amending Act of 1956 was published on December 31, 1956.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No. 429 of 1958, appellant's application for renewal of permit rejected in 1953, appeal allowed by State Transport Authority Tribunal on September 6, 1956, permit renewed from November 1, 1953 to October 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The facts in Civil Appeal No. 429 of 1958 are slightly different from those in other appeals and they may be stated The appellants application for renewal of his permanent permit was rejected in 1953 but, on appeal, the State Transport Authority Tribunal allowed his appeal on September 6,1956, and directed his permit to be renewed for three years beginning from November 1, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant in CA 429 applied for renewal on October 11, 1956, informed no action possible by Road Transport Authority, Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied on October 11, 1956, for the renewal of his permit and he was informed by the Road Transport Authority, Allahabad, that numberaction on his application, under reference was possible.

facts.text: Appellants in certain appeals (387-389,391-394,396-399,401,429) offered alternative routes, tentatively accepted but obtained stay and continued on old routes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in thirteen appeals, namely, Civil Appeals Nos. 387 to 389, 391 to 394, 396 to 399 and 401 and 429 were offered alternative routes. Though they tentatively accepted the offer,

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on January 15, 1959 by Das C.J. and Subba Rao J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. January 15. The judgment of Das, C. J., and Sinha, J., was delivered by Das, C. J. The judgment of Bhagwati, Subba Rao and Wanchoo, JJ., was delivered by Subba Rao, J.

facts.text: Das C.J. agrees with Subba Rao J. that appeals should be dismissed, though not all reasons.

anchor.surface_text: DAS, C. J.-We have had the advantage of perusing the judgment prepared by our learned Brother Subba Rao and we agree with the order proposed by him, namely, that all the above appeals should be dismissed with companyts, although we do number subscribe to all the reasons advanced by him.

facts.text: Constitution Fourth Amendment Act, 1955 received assent on April 27, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution  Fourth Amendment  Act, 1955, received the assent of the President on April 27, 1955.

facts.text: Scheme framed and approved between rejection of appellant's renewal application and appeal allowance in CA 429.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of nationalisation was initiated and finally approved between the date of the rejection of the appellants application for renewal and the date when his appeal was allowed.

facts.text: High Court granted certificates under Articles 132 and 133 of Constitution for appeals to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: These twenty-five appeals are by certificate under Arts. 132 and 133 of the Constitution granted by the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad

facts.text: All appeals consolidated by order of High Court.

anchor.surface_text: All the appeals were companysolidated by order of the High Court.

facts.text: Petitioner in CA 429 contends no notice given before scheme approved for his route.

anchor.surface_text: In addition, he companytended that in Appeal No. 429 of 1958, the scheme, in so far as it affected the appellants route was bad inasmuch as numbernotice was given to him before the scheme was approved.

facts.text: New grounds allowed in Supreme Court appeals regarding effect of Motor Vehicles Amendment Act 1956 on U.P. Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed applications for permission to urge new grounds in the appeals, which were number taken before the High Court. ... In the circumstances, we thought it to be a fit case for allowing the appellants to raise the new grounds and we accordingly gave them the permission.

issues.text: Whether the Uttar Pradesh Transport Services Development Act, 1955 became wholly void under Article 254(1) of the Constitution upon the passing of the Motor Vehicles Amendment Act, 1956 due to repugnancy

anchor.surface_text: U. P. Act, did -not, on the passing of the Motor Vehicles Amendment Act, 1956 100 of 1956 , hereinafter referred to as the Central Act, become wholly void under Art. 254 1  of the Constitution but continued to be a valid and subsisting law supporting the scheme already framed under the U. P. Act

issues.text: Whether, even if the Central Act amounts to a repeal of the U.P. Act under Article 254(2), such repeal destroys the scheme framed under the U.P. Act or is saved by Section 6 of the General Clauses Act

anchor.surface_text: even if the Central Act be construed as amounting, under Art. 254 2 , to a repeal of the U. P. Act, such repeal did not destroy or efface the scheme already framed under the U. P. Act, for the provisions of s. 6 of the General Clauses Act saved the same

issues.text: Whether the U.P. Act offends Article 31 of the Constitution as it stood before the 4th Amendment, particularly regarding adequate compensation under Section 11(5)

anchor.surface_text: the U. P. Act did not offend the provisions of Art. 31 of the Constitution, as it stood before the Constitution 4th Amendment Act, 1955, for. the P. Act and in particular s. 11 5 thereof provided for the payment of adequate compensation

issues.text: Whether the provisions of Part III of the Constitution are mere checks or limitations on legislative competency conferred by Articles 245 and 246 or an integral part thereof

anchor.surface_text: In view of the aforesaid finding that the U. P. Act did not infringe the fundamental rights guaranteed by Art. 31, it is wholly unnecessary to discuss the following questions, namely, a whether the provisions of Part III of the Constitution enshrining the fundamental rights are mere checks or limitations on the legislative competency conferred on Parliament and the State Legislatures by Arts. 245 and 246

issues.text: Whether the doctrine of eclipse is applicable only to pre-Constitution laws or also to post-Constitution laws falling under Article 13(2)

anchor.surface_text: b whether the doctrine of eclipse is applicable only to pre-Constitution laws or can apply also to any post-Constitution law which falls under Art. 13 2 of the Constitution. As, however, our learned Brother has thought fit to embark upon a discussion of these questions

issues.text: Whether the amendment of the Constitution (4th Amendment) removing a constitutional limitation validates a prior Act made when the power was subject to that limitation

anchor.surface_text: The question raised by the learned Advocate General may be posed thus whether the amendment of the Constitution removing a constitutional limitation on a legislature to make a particular law has the effect of validating the Act made by it when its power was subject to that limitation.

issues.text: Whether post-Constitution laws violating fundamental rights under Article 13(2) are void ab initio or merely eclipsed

anchor.surface_text: Article 13 2 deals with post-Constitution laws and declares laws made in contravention void to extent of contravention ... Post-Constitution laws violating Part III are void ab initio, still-born, nullity from inception

issues.text: Whether the Motor Vehicles Amendment Act, 1956 is wholly repugnant to the U.P. Act under Article 254(1), leaving no valid law to prohibit carrying on motor transport business

anchor.surface_text: i The Motor Vehicles Amendment Act 100 of 1956 passed by, the Parliament is wholly repugnant to the provisions of the U. P Act and therefore the latter became void under the provisions of Article 254 1 of the Constitution with the result that, at the present time, there is no valid law whereunder the Government can prohibit the appellants from exercising their fundamental right

issues.text: Whether the scheme under U.P. Act is an instrument under s.68B of Amending Act, rendering it inoperative post-Amendment Act

anchor.surface_text: ii the scheme framed under the Act, being one made to operate in future and from day to day, is an instrument within the meaning of s. 68B of the Amending Act, and therefore the provisions of the Amending Act would prevail over those of the scheme, and after the Amending Act came into force, it would have no operative force

issues.text: Whether schemes framed under U.P. Act before Amending Act are repugnant or saved, as opposed to future schemes

arguments.claim: The Motor Vehicles Amendment Act 1956 passed by Parliament is wholly repugnant to the provisions of the U.P. Act and therefore the latter became void under Article 254(1) of the Constitution with the result that there is no valid law whereunder the Government can prohibit the appellants from carrying on their business of motor transport

holdings.text: The Uttar Pradesh Transport Services Development Act, 1955 did not, on the passing of the Motor Vehicles Amendment Act, 1956, become wholly void under Art. 254(1) of the Constitution but continued to be a valid and subsisting law supporting the scheme already framed under the U.P. Act

anchor.surface_text: 1  that the Uttar Pradesh Transport Service  Development  Act, 1955  Act IX of 1955 , hereinafter referred to as the U. P. Act, did -not, on the passing of the Motor Vehicles  Amendment  Act, 1956  100 of 1956 , hereinafter referred to as the Central Act, become wholly void under Art. 254 1  of the Constitution but continued to be a valid and subsisting law supporting the scheme already framed under the U. P. Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repugnancy under Art.254(1) does not void the entire U.P. Act but only to the extent of inconsistency; prior schemes supported by remaining valid provisions

holdings.text: Even if the Central Act be construed as amounting, under Art. 254(2), to a repeal of the U.P. Act, such repeal did not destroy or efface the scheme already framed under the U.P. Act, for the provisions of s.6 of the General Clauses Act saved the same

anchor.surface_text: 2  that, even if the Central Act be construed as amounting, under Art. 254 2 , to a repeal of the U. P. Act, such repeal did number destroy or efface the scheme already framed under the U. P. Act, for the provisions of s. 6 of the General Clauses Act saved the same

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 6 General Clauses Act preserves prior actions/schemes done under repealed act, even if repugnancy leads to repeal under Art.254(2)

holdings.text: The U.P. Act did not offend the provisions of Art. 31 of the Constitution, as it stood before the Constitution (4th Amendment) Act, 1955, for the U.P. Act and in particular s.11(5) thereof provided for the payment of adequate compensation

anchor.surface_text: 3  that the U. P. Act did number offend the provisions of Art. 31 of the Constitution, as it stood before the Constitution  4th Amendment  Act, 1955, for. the P. Act and in particular s. 11 5  thereof provided for the payment of adequate compensation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 11(5) U.P. Act provides compensation per Schedule I, satisfying 'adequate compensation' under pre-amendment Art.31(2) for loss of permit/interest

holdings.text: Post-Constitution laws made in contravention of Part III (fundamental rights) are void ab initio to the extent of contravention under Art.13(2); they are still-born nullities from inception

anchor.surface_text: Article 13 2 deals with post-Constitution laws and declares laws made in contravention void to extent of contravention ... Post-Constitution laws violating Part III are void ab initio, still-born, nullity from inception

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.13(2) prohibits and declares void post-const laws abridging FR; legislative power under Arts.245/246 subject to Part III; distinguished from pre-const eclipse; American authorities and precedents like Saghir Ahmad support voidness

holdings.text: Amendment of Constitution (4th Amendment) removing limitation does not validate prior post-Constitution Act made when subject to that limitation; requires re-enactment

anchor.surface_text: whether the amendment of the Constitution removing a constitutional limitation on a legislature to make a particular law has the effect of validating the Act made by it when its power was subject to that limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Void ab initio laws cannot be revived by removing shadow (eclipse only for valid pre-const laws); precedents like Saghir Ahmad, Newberry v US require re-enactment

holdings.text: Motor Vehicles Amendment Act 1956 repugnant to U.P. Act under Art.254(1) for schemes initiated after Amending Act (occupies field, direct conflicts in procedure, authority); Central Act prevails; prior schemes under U.P. Act unaffected

anchor.surface_text: Repugnancy between two statutes may thus be ascertained on the basis of the following three principles Whether there is direct conflict between the two provisions Whether Parliament intended to lay down an exhaustive code ... It is therefore manifest that the Amending Act occupies the same field in respect of the schemes initiated after the Amending Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Three tests (direct conflict, exhaustive code, same field) applied: differences in initiator (Govt vs Undertaking), hearing authority (Board vs Govt), compensation, permit transfer; prospective application; prior schemes saved
